member.name: M:WW.Math.Transformation4D.GetPerspectiveProjectionTransform(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Gets the perspective transform based on given inverse tangents of the viewing frustrum angles and front clip, back clip planes.

remarks.para: The returned perspective transform is setup such that it can be used directly in OpenGL as the projection transform. The camera is positioned at the origin, looking towards the negative z-axis. The x-axis is pointing towards the right of the display, the y-axis points up.
This transformation matrix transforms coordinates within the viewing frustrum to a cube with coordinate ranges (-1, 1), which is convenient for clipping.

member.param: The cotangent of mu where mu is the angle between the z-axis (pointing towards the camera) and the line passing through the camera and the left side of the display.
The cotangent of nu where nu is the angle between the z-axis (pointing towards the camera) and the line passing through the camera and the top side of the display.
The front clip plane z-value closest to the camera (> 0).
The back clip plane z-value furthest from the camera (> 0).

member.name: M:WW.Math.Transformation4D.GetPerspectiveProjectionTransform(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Gets the perspective projection transform based on given viewing frustrum dimensions.
member.param: The x-coordinate of the left of the viewing frustrum near face.
The x-coordinate of the right the viewing frustrum near face.
The y-coordinate of the bottom the viewing frustrum near face.
The y-coordinate of the top the viewing frustrum near face.
The front clip plane z-value closest to the camera (> 0).
The back clip plane z-value furthest from the camera (> 0).

remarks.para: The returned perspective transform is setup such that it can be used directly in OpenGL as the projection transform. The camera is positioned at the origin, looking towards the negative z-axis. The x-axis is pointing towards the right of the display, the y-axis points up.
This transformation matrix transforms coordinates within the viewing frustrum to a cube with coordinate ranges (-1, 1), which is convenient for clipping.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Transformation4D.GetOrthographicProjectionTransform(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Gets the orthographic projection transform based on given viewing volume dimensions.
member.param: The x-coordinate of the left of the viewing volume.
The x-coordinate of the right the viewing volume.
The y-coordinate of the bottom the viewing volume.
The y-coordinate of the top the viewing volume.
The front clip plane z-value closest to the camera (> 0 if in front of camera).
The back clip plane z-value furthest from the camera (> 0 if in front of camera).

remarks.para: The returned orthographic transform is setup such that it can be used directly in OpenGL as the projection transform. The camera is positioned at the origin, looking towards the negative z-axis. The x-axis is pointing towards the right of the display, the y-axis points up.
This transformation matrix transforms coordinates within the viewing volume to a cube with coordinate ranges (-1, 1), which is convenient for clipping.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Transformation4D.GetBoundsToScreenTransform(WW.Math.Bounds3D,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the bounds to screen transform.
member.remarks: This maps a model rectangle to a screen rectangle by applying an uniform scaling so that the source rectangle defined by its minimum and maximum coordinates fits into a screen (or image) rectangle with coordinate (0,0) in its upper left corner and defined by its width and height. The different orientation of the y axis in model and screen coordinates is taken care of. The model rectangle will always fit completely into the screen rectangle, but if the aspect ratios of both rectangles differ, a bit more of the model is mapped either at top and bottom or at the left and right side. The mapping is always done in a way that the model rectangles center will be mapped to the screen rectangles center.
member.param: The bounding box which shall be mapped. Z coordinate values will be ignored.
member.returns: Orthogonal transformation which maps model X and Y coordinates to screen X and Y coordinates, or if is not initialized.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Transformation4D.GetBoundsToScreenTransform(WW.Math.Bounds3D,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the bounds to screen transform.
member.remarks: This maps a model rectangle to a screen rectangle by applying an uniform scaling so that the source rectangle defined by its minimum and maximum coordinates fits into a screen (or image) rectangle with coordinate (0,0) in its upper left corner and defined by its width and height. The different orientation of the y axis in model and screen coordinates is taken care of. The model rectangle will always fit completely into the screen rectangle, but if the aspect ratios of both rectangles differ, a bit more of the model is mapped either at top and bottom or at the left and right side. The mapping is always done in a way that the model rectangles center will be mapped to the screen rectangles center.
member.param: The bounding box which shall be mapped. Z coordinate values will be ignored.
The additional margin to be left around the screen rectangle. Making this larger than half of the minimum of and will lead to unexpected results.
member.returns: Orthogonal transformation which maps model X and Y coordinates to screen X and Y coordinates, or if is not initialized.

member.name: T:WW.ComponentModel.SortedPropertiesTypeConverter
member.summary: This class makes it possible to: globalize property display names and desriptions, sort properties and set the DisplayName to a property with an attribute. Also all property characteristics can be changed dynamically if needed.
member.remarks:
Set a class's to this class to enable globalization and dynamic property characteristics.
The display name and description for a property are obtained from a resource file if specified by the . The resource file is expected to be named namespace.classname.resources. Resources are expected to be named PropertyName_DisplayName, PropertyName_Description PropertyName_Category (all optional). Also sorts using the attribute.
Specify for simpler usage (not globalized).
If a property has the attribute then the delegate specified is called for its runtime .
See also

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D
member.summary: This class represents a 2D polygon: a closed plane figure with n sides (in 2D).
member.remarks:
This class has methods to:
calculate the polygon area (),
to test whether a point is inside the polygon (),
test whether the polygon is clockwise or not (),
do boolean operations (, , ).
Further static methods are also provided to allow to use other data structures than Polygon2D.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.IShape2D.CreateIterator
member.summary: Creates an iterator over this shape.
member.remarks: It is expected that the returned iterator represents a snapshot of the shape's state as it is when the iterator is created via this property, i.e. changes which are applied to the shape after the iterator is constructed are not expected to be reflected by the iterator itself.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D.GetIntersection(System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D},System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D})
member.summary: Get the intersection of two given regions.

remarks.para: Each region is defined by a set of polygons. If a polygon is counter clockwise, it is filled, if it's clockwise it represents a hole. Polygons of one region may not intersect each other. A polygon may touch itself though.
The outer polygon must always be counter clockwise (if there are holes, the hole must always be a cutout of a non-hole).
Uses the as the precision.

member.returns: The polygons building the intersection of both lists.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D.GetIntersection(System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D},System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D},System.Double)

The outer polygon must always be counter clockwise (if there are holes, the hole must always be a cutout of a non-hole).

member.param: The precision used, a small but positive number.
member.returns: The polygons building the intersection of both lists.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D.GetWindingNumber(WW.Math.Point2D,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Point2D}})
member.summary: Gets the winding number of soecified point with respect to the combined polygons.
member.remarks: The winding number can be used to determine if a point is inside the polygon using the winding number. It depends on the definition of inside how this can be done. Useful definitions are an odd winding number, a positive winding number or a non-zero winding number.
member.param: Polygons used for winding number calculation.
member.returns: Combined number of windings around the given point.

member.remarks: The winding number can be used to determine if a point is inside the polygon using the winding number. It depends on the definition of inside how this can be done. Useful definitions are an odd winding number, a positive winding number or a non-zero winding number.
member.param: Polygons used for winding number calculation.
member.returns: Combined number of windings around the given point.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D.GetWindingNumber(WW.Math.Point2D,System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Point2D})
member.summary: Gets the winding number of specified point with respect to specified polygon.
member.remarks: The winding number can be used to determine if a point is inside the polygon using the winding number. It depends on the definition of inside how this can be done. Useful definitions are an odd winding number, a positive winding number or a non-zero winding number.
member.param: Point for which the winding number is looked up.
Polygon which possibly winds around the point.
member.return: The number of windings the given polyline does take around the given point. It is always 0 for points outside of the polygon, negative for clockwise winding and positive for counterclockwise winding.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D.GetConvexHull
member.summary: Calculates the convex hull using the Melkman algorithm (1987). This method assumes the specified polygon is a simple polygon (i.e. it does not cross itself).
member.remarks: The running time of this algorithm is O(n).

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D.GetConvexHull(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the convex hull using the Melkman algorithm (1987). This method assumes the specified polygon is a simple polygon (i.e. it does not cross itself).
member.remarks: The running time of this algorithm is O(n).

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D.GetConvexHull(System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Point2D})
member.summary: Calculates the convex hull using the Melkman algorithm (1987). This method assumes the specified polygon is a simple polygon (i.e. it does not cross itself). The input polygon is expected to be counter clockwise. The result is counter clockwise.
member.remarks: The running time of this algorithm is O(n).

member.remarks: The running time of this algorithm is O(n).

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D.BooleanOperations
member.summary: This class contains methods for doing boolean operations on 2D polygons.

remarks.para:
The following boolan operations are implemented:
Union: ,
Difference: ,
Intersection: ,
Exclusive or (symmetric difference): ,
This implementation replaces the older implementation, and is more robust and faster. The old implementation is still available here: .

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D.BooleanOperations.GetUnion(System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D},System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D})
member.summary: Get the union of two given regions.

remarks.para: Each region is defined by a set of polygons. If a polygon is counter clockwise, it is filled, if it's clockwise it represents a hole. Polygons of one region may not intersect each other. A polygon may touch itself though.
The outer polygon must always be counter clockwise (if there are holes, the hole must always be a cutout of a non-hole).
Uses the as the precision.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D.BooleanOperations.Event
member.summary: Represents an event for doing segment-segment intersection using a sweepline algorithm.
member.remarks: Events are sorted first along the x-axis, and then along the y-axis.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D.BooleanOperations.SweepLine
member.summary: Loosely based on bentley-ottman and "line segment intersection" by M. de Berg et al. However this implementation doesn't use a balanced search tree for ordering segments along the sweepline as it would be difficult to circumvent precision issues in case of multiple overlapping line segments.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D.BooleanOperations.SegmentWithIntersections.AddIntersection(WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D.BooleanOperations.Intersection)
member.summary: Adds the specified intersection. If there was already an intersection present with the same parameter or Point, than the intersection was not added, and the existing intersection is returned. If result was null, then intersection is at start or end point.

member.name: P:WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D.BooleanOperations.Intersection.Parameter
member.summary: Gets the parameter (0-1), 0 represents a segments start point, 1 represents the end point.

member.summary: Determine if a point is inside of a set of polygons.
member.remarks: Uses the winding number to compute whether the point is inside the polygons (). Returns true if the winding number is greater than zero.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D.BooleanOperations.Polygon
member.summary: Represents a polygon.
member.remarks: The IsInsidePolygons/GetWindingNumber are copied from Polygon2D and adapted.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D.BooleanOperations.Polygon.GetWindingNumber(WW.Math.Point2D,WW.Math.Geometry.Polygon2D.BooleanOperations.Polygon)
member.summary: Gets the winding number of specified point with respect to specified polygon.
member.remarks: The winding number can be used to determine if a point is inside the polygon using the winding number. It depends on the definition of inside how this can be done. Useful definitions are an odd winding number, a positive winding number or a non-zero winding number.

member.summary: Gets the winding number of specified point with respect to specified polygon.
member.remarks: The winding number can be used to determine if a point is inside the polygon using the winding number. It depends on the definition of inside how this can be done. Useful definitions are an odd winding number, a positive winding number or a non-zero winding number.

member.summary: A 4D shape which is defined by a transformed 2D shape.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.IShape4D
member.summary: The basic interface for 4D shapes.
member.remarks: A 4D shape is basically a flat 2D shape with an additional 4D transformation.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.IShape4D.CheckClipping(WW.Math.Geometry.IInsideTester4D)
member.summary: Make a shortcut check whether this shape is to be handled by clipping.
member.remarks: Usually a reduced set of points which are corners of a simple bounding object need to be checked.
member.param: Clipping region against which to check.
member.returns: The result of the check. As this is only an optimization you may always return which means that finer grade algorithms will kick in, but that will of course slow down rendering algorithms using this method.

member.summary: Transform this shape with the given transformation modelTransform.

member.summary: Create a set of 4D polylines from this shape.
member.returns: A list of polylines representing a flattened version of this shape.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.IShape4D.ToShape2D(WW.Math.Matrix4D)
member.summary: Create a 2D shape from this shape.
member.remarks: The points of the path are the projection on the x-y plane, i.e. z is 0.
member.returns: A 2D shape being a projection of this shape to the x-y plane after the transformation is applied.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.IShape4D.ToGraphicsPath(WW.Math.Matrix4D)
member.summary: Create a Windows graphics path from this shape.
member.remarks: The points of the path are the projection on the x-y plane, i.e. z is 0.
member.returns: a graphics path being a projection of this shape

member.name: T:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Triangulator2LR
member.summary: 2D triangulator that can triangulate polygons with holes.

remarks.para: The polygons may not cross each other.
The algorithm used is a Constrained Delaunay triangulation.

member.example:
Below is an example demonstrating triangulating a square polygon with a hole in it. The hole is a smaller square.
This is the output of the triangulation:
(-2, 2), (1, 1), (-1, 1)
(-1, -1), (-2, 2), (-1, 1)
(1, 1), (2, 2), (1, -1)
(-2, 2), (2, 2), (1, 1)
(2, -2), (-1, -1), (1, -1)
(2, 2), (2, -2), (1, -1)
(-1, -1), (-2, -2), (-2, 2)
(2, -2), (-2, -2), (-1, -1)

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Triangulator2LR.Triangulate(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Point2LR}},System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Triangulator2LR.Triangle},System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Point2LR})
member.summary: Triangulates given polygons and returns triangles and points.
member.param: Input. The polygons may not cross each other.
Output triangles, only contains the triangle point indices.
Output points, referred to by the point indices in the output triangles.

remarks.para: The polygons may not cross each other.
The algorithm used is a Constrained Delaunay triangulation.

member.example:
Below is an example demonstrating triangulating a square polygon with a hole in it. The hole is a smaller square.
This is the output of the triangulation:
(-2, 2), (1, 1), (-1, 1)
(-1, -1), (-2, 2), (-1, 1)
(1, 1), (2, 2), (1, -1)
(-2, 2), (2, 2), (1, 1)
(2, -2), (-1, -1), (1, -1)
(2, 2), (2, -2), (1, -1)
(-1, -1), (-2, -2), (-2, 2)
(2, -2), (-2, -2), (-1, -1)

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Triangulator2LR.Triangulate(System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Point2LR},System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Int32}},System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Triangulator2LR.Triangle})
member.summary: Triangulates given point set and polylines.
member.param: Represents polylines of fixed edges. May be empty or null. Each integer is an index in the inputPoints.

remarks.para: The polygons may not cross each other.
The algorithm used is a Constrained Delaunay triangulation.
This method may skip points that are very close together, in that case also the point index lists are modified.

member.example:
Below is an example demonstrating triangulating five points resulting in three triangles. The second triangulation is the same as the first one, but with one edge fixed (which forces more skinny triangles in this particular case).
This is the output of the first triangulation:
(2, 2), (-2, -2), (-2, 2)
(2, 2), (4, 0), (2, -2)
(2, -2), (-2, -2), (2, 2)
This is the output of the second triangulation:
(-2, -2), (4, 0), (2, -2)
(4, 0), (-2, -2), (2, 2)
(2, 2), (-2, -2), (-2, 2)

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Triangulator2LR.Triangulate(System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Point2LR},System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Int32}},System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Triangulator2LR.Triangle},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Triangulates given point set and polylines.
member.param: Represents polylines of fixed edges. May be empty or null. Each integer is an index in the inputPoints.
if set to true removes super triangles when finished triangulating.

remarks.para: The polygons may not cross each other.
The algorithm used is a Constrained Delaunay triangulation.
This method may skip points that are very close together, in that case also the point index lists are modified.

member.name: T:WW.Collections.Generic.LookupList`2
member.summary: Represents a list with dictionary lookup by a key (doesn't have to be unique).
member.remarks: The method (and therefore also ) is not made faster by the dictionary lookup and therefore is still O(n). Lookup by key is made faster by dictionary lookup. Inserting duplicate keys becomes slow when there are many O(n * n), this implementation assumes lookup is more common than insertion.

member.name: T:WW.Actions.IInteractor
member.summary: An Interface for interactor objects that allow mouse interactions.
member.remarks: An interactor may or may not process input events depending on whether the interactor is active (see the property). E.g. imagine a line entity being selected, and its two control point boxes are shown that allow the user to drag them. When the user isn't a dragging a control point, then the mouse move/mouse up events should be ignored by the interactor: the interactor is not active. But when the user clicks a control point, then the interactor becomes active, and the interactor starts processing the mouse move and mouse button up events. When the mouse button up event is processed, the interactor is deactivated again.

But when the user clicks a control point, then the interactor becomes active, and the interactor starts processing the mouse move and mouse button up events. When the mouse button up event is processed, the interactor is deactivated again.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.IInsideTester4D.TryIsInside(WW.Math.Bounds3D)
member.summary: Returns whether the specified box is inside/outside a region or returns if the result could not be calculated cheaply. E.g. when doing an inside test where both end points of a line segment are outside of a rectangle, but the segment might still intersect the rectangle.
member.remarks: This may allow shortcuts, when bounds calculation is cheap or may be precalculated. In the case of returning no handling of the objects making up the bounds is necessary, in the case of returning the objects making up the bounds can be handled without caring for clipping.
member.param: Bounding box. If box is invalid, is returned. In most cases this can be handled like
member.returns: The result of checking the clipped bounds.

member.summary: Gets the center of the segment.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Segment2BR.GetDelta
member.summary: Gets minus .

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Segment2BR.GetIntersectionParameters(WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Segment2BR,WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Segment2BR,WW.Math.Exact.BigRational[]@,WW.Math.Exact.BigRational[]@)
member.summary: Calculate intersection parameter between two line segments.
member.remarks: The result is the solution of equation .Start + p * .GetDelta = .Start + q * .GetDelta.
member.param: A single parameter has a value between BigRational.Zero and BigRational.One. If the lines are parallel, the start p and end p of the overlapping line are returned. Lowest p value is first in the array. If the lines don't intersect then null is returned.
Analogue to . When lines are parallel, q values are returned in the order that the corresponding points are with respect to the p values.
member.returns: true if intersection occurred.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Segment2BR.Intersects(WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Segment2BR,WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Segment2BR)
member.summary: Calculates if 2 line segment intersect.

member.summary: Returns true if given point is on the line segment.

member.summary: Returns the smallest squared distance between the line segment and specified point.

member.summary: Returns the point on this segment that is closest to the specified point.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Segment2BR.GetNormalizedProjection(WW.Math.Exact.Point2BR)
member.summary: Gets the projection of specified point onto this segment, normalized such that the projection of the start point is 0 and of the end point is 1. Returns NaN if this segment has a zero length.
member.remarks: Returns the distance from this segment's start point in the direction of the end point, normalized to 0-1 when the point's projection falls between the start and end point.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2LR
member.summary: This class represents a 2D polygon: a closed plane figure with n sides (in 2D).
member.remarks:
This class has methods to:
calculate the polygon area (),
to test whether a point is inside the polygon (),
test whether the polygon is clockwise or not (),
do boolean operations (, , ).
Further static methods are also provided to allow to use other data structures than Polygon2LR.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2LR.GetCentroid
member.summary: Calculates the centroid of a polygon (also known as the center of mass).
member.remarks: The polygon may not be self intersecting.
member.returns: The centroid or null if the polygon has no points.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2LR.GetCentroid(WW.Math.Exact.LongRational@)
member.summary: Calculates the centroid of a polygon (also known as the center of mass) and the area of the polygon.
member.remarks: Clockwise polygons will result in a negative area. The polygon may not be self intersecting.
member.returns: The centroid or null if the polygon has no points.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2LR.IsConvex
member.summary: Is this polygon convex?
member.returns: true if the polygon is convex, false if it is not convex.

member.summary: Determine if a point is inside of this polygon.
member.remarks: Uses the winding number to compute whether the point is inside the polygon (). Returns true if the winding number's value is odd.

member.summary: Gets the number of intersections between a ray and a polygon.

member.summary: Returns whether the polygon is clockwise.
member.remarks: The polygon may not be self intersecting.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2LR.GetArea
member.summary: Gets the area of the polygon.
member.remarks: Clockwise polygons will result in a negative area. The polygon may not be self intersecting.
member.returns: The area, where clockwise polygons will result in a negative area.

member.summary: Gets the reverse polygon (useful to change polygon from clockwise to counter clockwise and vice versa).

member.remarks: Uses the Jordan Curve theorem.

member.summary: Determine if a point is inside of a set of polygons.

member.summary: Determine if a point is inside of a set of polygons.
member.remarks: Uses the winding number to compute whether the point is inside the polygons (). Returns true if the winding number's value is odd.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2LR.GetWindingNumber(WW.Math.Exact.Point2LR,System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Point2LR})
member.summary: Gets the winding number of specified point with respect to specified polygon.
member.remarks: The winding number can be used to determine if a point is inside the polygon using the winding number. It depends on the definition of inside how this can be done. Useful definitions are an odd winding number, a positive winding number or a non-zero winding number.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2LR.GetConvexHull
member.summary: Calculates the convex hull using the Melkman algorithm (1987). This method assumes the specified polygon is a simple polygon (i.e. it does not cross itself).
member.remarks: The running time of this algorithm is O(n).

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2LR.GetConvexHull(System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Point2LR})
member.summary: Calculates the convex hull using the Melkman algorithm (1987). This method assumes the specified polygon is a simple polygon (i.e. it does not cross itself). The input polygon is expected to be counter clockwise. The result is counter clockwise.
member.remarks: The running time of this algorithm is O(n).

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2LR.GetIntersection(System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2LR},System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2LR})
member.summary: Get the intersection of two given regions.

remarks.para: Each region is defined by a set of polygons. If a polygon is counter clockwise, it is filled, if it's clockwise it represents a hole. Polygons of one region may not intersect each other. A polygon may touch itself though.
The outer polygon must always be counter clockwise (if there are holes, the hole must always be a cutout of a non-hole).

member.returns: The polygons building the intersection of both lists.
member.example: This is a simple example of getting the intersection of two regions.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2LR.GetDifference(System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2LR},System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2LR})
member.summary: Get the difference of two given regions (region2 is subtracted from region1).

remarks.para: Each region is defined by a set of polygons. If a polygon is counter clockwise, it is filled, if it's clockwise it represents a hole. Polygons of one region may not intersect each other. A polygon may touch itself though.
The outer polygon must always be counter clockwise (if there are holes, the hole must always be a cutout of a non-hole).

member.returns: The polygons building the difference of the first minus the second list.
member.example: This is a simple example of getting the difference of two regions.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2LR.GetUnion(System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2LR},System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2LR})
member.summary: Get the union of two given regions.

remarks.para: Each region is defined by a set of polygons. If a polygon is counter clockwise, it is filled, if it's clockwise it represents a hole. Polygons of one region may not intersect each other. A polygon may touch itself though.
The outer polygon must always be counter clockwise (if there are holes, the hole must always be a cutout of a non-hole).

member.returns: The polygons building the union of the first and the second region.
member.example: This is a simple example of getting the union of two regions.

member.returns: The polygons building the exclusive or of the first and the second region.

Union:
Difference:

member.summary: Collect polygon from given start segment.

the result region to which to add the result polygon
the function to determine whether or not to include a segment

Get next unprocessed segment given current segment. Return value might be null. Uses either in or out segments at the current point, assuming the segments direction might need reversal. This is used for cleaning up self intersecting polygons (with potential overlapping parts) and splitting them into proper polygons.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2LR.BooleanOperations.SweepLine
member.summary: Loosely based on bentley-ottman and "line segment intersection" by M. de Berg et al. TODO: Remark from the double-precision implementation of this algorithm: However this implementation doesn't use a balanced search tree for ordering segments along the sweepline as it would be difficult to circumvent precision issues in case of multiple overlapping line segments. For big rationals there are no precision issues, so can implement this more accurately.

member.name: T:WW.Actions.SimpleTransformationProvider2D
member.summary: A simple transformation provider suitable for 2D views.

remarks.para: Set the ViewWindow and call to initialize this class.
The basic difference with the 3D version is that a 2D does not allow for perspective settings and does a better fit of the displayed model.

member.name: T:WW.Actions.SimpleTransformationProviderBase
member.summary: A transformation provider which allows to define the provided transformations by a chain of simpler transformations.

remarks.para: Set the and call to initialize this class.

The underlying idea is that the viewer is placed at the center of the coordinate system, and looking into -Z direction with X pointing right and Y pointing up (in DXF world coordinates, see ). So the first step is to place everything in a way that it is visible (i.e. the model is lying on the view axis in front of the viewer). This is done by the which is build from 3 (for 2D) or 4 (for 3D) simple transformations applied in the following order:
Project the model using either to project the model into screen space, or to project the model into a screen independent space where both X and Y are in the range -1 to 1.
The method is preparing all settings in a way that a model with a given bounding box is visible.

member.name: P:WW.Actions.Interactor.Transaction
member.summary: Gets the transaction (optional). By default returns null. Only one interactor that has a transaction should be active at the same time. As soon as the transaction is committed/rolled back, another interactor with transaction may be started.

remarks.para: If an interactor internally uses a transaction, it means the interaction goes through several steps which the user should be able to undo/redo. When the transaction is committed, a event should be raised that contains the command that represents the transaction (this may be the transaction itself, but typically isn't, as the commands inside the transaction may also affect the interactor itself, and when the transaction is committed, it's more efficient to discard that weight). Example: creating of a text entity might require 3 steps. First the position has to be determined (by mouse click). Then the text height has to be entered (in a text box). And then the text itself has to be entered (for which each key stroke is a command). Then when the user presses enter, one single command goes onto the undo stack: the command that adds the text, the transaction itself is no longer needed as there's no need to record all the individual key strokes onto the undo stack once the transaction is committed. And when the user presses escape, the text is not added and the transaction is discarded.
If an interactor does not use a transaction, then the interactor does not have any internal stages to go through that should be undoable, and it will typically just raise a event when appropriate.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.Plane3D.GetIntersection(WW.Math.Geometry.Segment3D)
member.summary: Gets the intersection between specified segment and this plane.
member.remarks: If the segment is parallel to plane, and the segment is on this plane then the middle of the segment is returned.
member.returns: The intersection if there is an intersection. Returns null otherwise.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.Plane3D.GetIntersection(WW.Math.Geometry.Segment3D,System.Double@)
member.summary: Gets the intersection between specified segment and this plane.
member.remarks: If the segment is parallel to plane, and the segment is on this plane then the middle of the segment is returned.
member.param: The segment to test for intersection.
The intersection point = segment.Start + u * segment.GetDelta().
member.returns: The intersection if there is an intersection. Returns null otherwise.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.Plane3D.GetIntersectionCoefficient(WW.Math.Geometry.Segment3D)
member.summary: Gets the intersection between specified segment and this plane.
member.remarks: If the segment is parallel to plane, and the segment is on this plane then the middle of the segment is returned.
member.returns: The intersection coefficient u if there is an intersection, where the intersection point = segment.Start + u * segment.GetDelta(). Returns null otherwise.

member.summary: Gets the intersection between specified ray and this plane.
member.remarks: If the ray is parallel to plane, and the ray is on this plane then the origin of the ray is returned.
member.returns: The intersection if there is an intersection. Returns null otherwise.

member.summary: Gets the intersection between specified ray and this plane.
member.remarks: If the ray is parallel to plane, and the ray is on this plane then the origin of the ray is returned.
member.param: The ray to test for intersection.

member.name: T:WW.Actions.SimpleTransformationProvider3D
member.summary: A simple transformation provider suitable for 3D views.

remarks.para: Set the ViewWindow and call to initialize this class.
The basic difference with the 2D version is that a 3D view allows perspective projections.

member.summary: Sets the view scaling size.

member.summary: Store the state of this provider into a mapping.

member.summary: Restore the state of this provider from a mapping.

member.summary: Sets/gets whether the view projection is perspective.

member.summary: Gets the canonical projection transform.

member.name: P:WW.Actions.SimpleTransformationProvider3D.CameraDistance
member.summary: Gets or sets the camera distance.
member.remarks: The model is moved from the away by this value. In case of a perspectival projection this is also the distance where the is valid.

member.name: P:WW.Actions.SimpleTransformationProvider3D.ViewScalingSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the view scaling size.

member.name: P:WW.Actions.SimpleTransformationProvider3D.CameraDistanceTransform
member.summary: Get the transformation defined by the .

member.name: P:WW.Actions.SimpleTransformationProvider3D.FrontClipDistance
member.summary: Gets or sets the front clip distance.
member.remarks: Objects nearer to the viewer than this distance are discarded. Hardware accelerated graphics systems like OpenGL, DirectX or XNA require this value to be greater than 0 (i.e. 0 itself is not allowed), and the z buffering may produce bad results if the ratio of / is becoming too large.

member.name: P:WW.Actions.SimpleTransformationProvider3D.BackClipDistance
member.summary: Gets or sets the back clip distance.
member.remarks: Objects farer wawy from the viewer than this distance are discarded. HAs to be greater than or nothing will be visible. Hardware accelerated graphics systems like OpenGL, DirectX or XNA may produce bad z buffering results if the ratio of / is becoming too large.

member.name: P:WW.Actions.SimpleTransformationProvider3D.WorldTransform
member.summary: Get the world transformation.
member.remarks: The world transformation prepares the model, i.e. it places it correctly according to the view axis and rotates it.

member.name: T:WW.Actions.InteractorWithMouseButtonDownFilter
member.summary: This interactor is a wrapper for easily binding a wrapped interactor to a mouse button.
member.remarks: This interactor wrapper checks if the mouse down flags match the specified , and if true then it activates the wrapped interactor and lets it process the mouse down event, otherwise the method returns false.

member.name: E:WW.Actions.InteractorWrapper.Activated
member.summary: This event is raised when the interactor is activated (see ).
member.remarks: An interactor may or may not process input events depending on whether the interactor is active (see the property). E.g. imagine a line entity being selected, and its two control point boxes are shown that allow the user to drag them. When the user isn't a dragging a control point, then the mouse move/mouse up events should be ignored by the interactor: the interactor is not active. But when the user clicks a control point, then the interactor becomes active, and the interactor starts processing the mouse move and mouse button up events. When the mouse button up event is processed, the interactor is deactivated again.

member.name: E:WW.Actions.InteractorWrapper.Deactivated
member.summary: This event is raised when the interactor is deactivated (see ).
member.remarks: An interactor may or may not process input events depending on whether the interactor is active (see the property). E.g. imagine a line entity being selected, and its two control point boxes are shown that allow the user to drag them. When the user isn't a dragging a control point, then the mouse move/mouse up events should be ignored by the interactor: the interactor is not active. But when the user clicks a control point, then the interactor becomes active, and the interactor starts processing the mouse move and mouse button up events. When the mouse button up event is processed, the interactor is deactivated again.

member.name: P:WW.Actions.InteractorWrapper.IsEnabled
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this interactor is enabled. If not enabled the behavior is disabled and e.g. the interactor does not active.

member.name: P:WW.Actions.InteractorWrapper.IsActive
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this interactor is active.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.Triangulator2D
member.summary: 2D triangulator that can triangulate polygons with holes.

remarks.para: The polygons may not cross each other.
The algorithm used is a Constrained Delaunay triangulation.

remarks.para: The polygons may not cross each other.
The algorithm used is a Constrained Delaunay triangulation.

Output triangles, only contains the triangle point indices.
Output points, referred to by the point indices in the output triangles.

member.summary: Triangulates given point set and polylines.

remarks.para: The polygons may not cross each other.
The algorithm used is a Constrained Delaunay triangulation.
This method may skip points that are very close together, in that case also the point index lists are modified.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.Triangulator2D.Triangle.DivideInThree(System.Int32,WW.Math.Geometry.Triangulator2D.TriangulatorContext,System.Collections.Generic.Stack{WW.Math.Geometry.Triangulator2D.Triangle})
member.summary: Replace this triangle by 3 new triangles.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.Triangulator2D.Triangle.DivideInThree(System.Int32,WW.Math.Geometry.Triangulator2D.TriangulatorContext,System.Collections.Generic.List{WW.Math.Geometry.Triangulator2D.Triangle},System.Int32,System.Collections.Generic.Stack{WW.Math.Geometry.Triangulator2D.Triangle})
member.summary: Replace this sweep line triangle by 3 new triangles.
member.remarks: This triangle's first point is the super triangle top point. 2 of the result triangles will be sweep line triangles and will share this point. For each resulting sweep line triangle, the super triangle top point is kept as the triangle's first point, such that edge 0 is always on the left side, edge 1 is on the bottom and edge 2 is on the right side. By keeping this convention, the left/right tests can be simpler and faster.

member.summary: Creates 2 triangles such of the new triangles 2 of the 3 edges remain at the same index. The sweep triangle point always remains at index 0. The 2 triangles are created in clockwise order along the divided edge.
member.remarks: Depending on how the triangle is split, of the 2 resulting triangles either 1 or 2 are sweep line triangles. For each resulting sweep line triangle, the super triangle top point is kept as the triangle's first point, such that edge 0 is always on the left side, edge 1 is on the bottom and edge 2 is on the right side. By keeping this convention, the left/right tests can be simpler and faster.

member.summary: Try to replace neighbour. Note that e0 and e1 must be in clockwise direction.

member.summary: Algorithm based on barycentric coordinates. (see http://www.ddj.com/184404201, Dr Dobbs, Triangle Intersection Tests).
member.remarks: Just keeping this method for future reference. (Is about 50% slower than the method using three outside tests).

member.remarks: This is often called the inCircle test in literature. Note that points a, b and c MUST be in clockwise order (otherwise sign of the determinant changes).

member.name: P:WW.Math.Geometry.Triangulator2D.Triangle.Edge0HasOddFixCount
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether edge 0 has an odd fix count, i.e. if 3 then edge 0 was fixed 3 times, this could happen when 3 polylines run over this edge. Depending on the definition of inside/outside, when odd, the edge is a transition from inside to outside, when even, both sides are either inside/outside.

member.name: P:WW.Math.Geometry.Triangulator2D.Triangle.Edge1HasOddFixCount
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether edge 1 has an odd fix count, i.e. if 3 then edge 0 was fixed 3 times, this could happen when 3 polylines run over this edge. Depending on the definition of inside/outside, when odd, the edge is a transition from inside to outside, when even, both sides are either inside/outside.

member.name: P:WW.Math.Geometry.Triangulator2D.Triangle.Edge2HasOddFixCount
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether edge 2 has an odd fix count, i.e. if 3 then edge 0 was fixed 3 times, this could happen when 3 polylines run over this edge. Depending on the definition of inside/outside, when odd, the edge is a transition from inside to outside, when even, both sides are either inside/outside.

member.summary: Returns whether p is contained in the triangle specified by p0, p1, p2.
member.param: The on edge flags (only valid when return value is true): 0 is not on an edge, 1 is on the edge starting at p0, 2 is on the edge starting at p1, 4 is on the edge starting at p2.
member.remarks: The triangle points must be in clockwise order! This method is slower than the one not taking any precision argument.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.Triangle2D.ContainsPoint(WW.Math.Point2D,WW.Math.Point2D,WW.Math.Point2D,WW.Math.Point2D,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Returns whether p is contained in the triangle specified by p0, p1, p2.
member.param: Index of edge to skip checking (e.g. if it was already checked elsewhere). Pass 0-2 to skip check a certain edge, or -1 to check all edges.
The on edge flags (only valid when return value is true): 0 is not on an edge, 1 is on the edge starting at p0, 2 is on the edge starting at p1, 4 is on the edge starting at p2.
Index of the edge (between 0 and 2) outside which the point is if the result is false, -1 otherwise.
member.returns: true if the specified p contains point; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: The triangle points must be in clockwise order! This method is slower than the one not taking any precision argument.

member.name: T:WW.Collections.Generic.ActiveLookupList`2
member.summary: Represents an active list with dictionary lookup by a key (doesn't have to be unique). Provides events that are raised when the list is modified.
member.remarks: The method (and therefore also ) is not made faster by the dictionary lookup and therefore is still O(n). Lookup by key is made faster by dictionary lookup. Inserting duplicate keys becomes slow when there are many O(n * n), this implementation assumes lookup is more common than insertion.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Vector3D.GetAngle(WW.Math.Vector3D,WW.Math.Vector3D,WW.Math.Vector3D)
member.summary: Returns the angle in radians between given two vectors.
member.remarks: This special helper method is returning an angle in the range 0 to pi if both the axis defined by the cross product of a and b points into a similar direction as the axis, and between pi and 2 pi if both point in different directions.
member.returns: The angle between both vectors in radians in the range 0 to 2 pi, 0.0 if one of the vectors has no length.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Vector3D.GetAngleAroundAxis(WW.Math.Vector3D,WW.Math.Vector3D,WW.Math.Vector3D)
member.summary: Get the rotation angle between two vectors around a given axis.
member.remarks: As both vectors may have different angles to the axis itself, the returned rotation angle will only give the best fit for the rotation. This is the rotation angle which will rotate the projection of into a plane perpendicular to the axis to the projection of into the same plane.
member.returns: Angle in radians between 0 and 2 pi.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.Polyline2D.Subdivide1
member.summary: Contains methods for calculating intersections between polylines. The methods in this class return the subdivided polylines, but of each point in the polyline no information is added whether this was an original point, or an intersection point. For more intersection methods that return more detailed information see class .

member.summary: Gets the intersections between specified arcs.
member.param:
The intersections, one of the three following possibilities:
null if there is no intersection.
An array with 1 element if the arcs touch.
An array with 2 element if the arcs intersect eachother at 2 points or overlap (partially).
Resulting overlapping arcs in case the arcs overlap, null otherwise. If the arcs overlap, contains either 1 or 2 elements.
member.returns: Returns true if there are either intersections or overlapping arcs.

member.name: P:WW.Math.Geometry.Arc2D.IncludedAngle
member.summary: Gets the included angle (radians).
member.remarks: Gets the included angle between the start and end angle. Note that this angle is always positive, as this arc class is always counter clock wise. So if the start angle is 1.3 * and the end angle is 0.2 * , then the included angle = ((2 + 0.2) - 1.3) * = 0.9 * .

q has value between 0 and 1 when there is 1 intersection. When the ray and segment are parallel, then p is set to .
is set to true when the line and segment are parallel.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.GeneralShape2D
member.summary: A general shape which can contain all kinds of segments.
member.remarks: As a special optimization which makes iterating over a general shape a cheap operation an object of this class can be fixated (see and ). If this is done, no further changes are allowed to it. If a change is tried, an will be thrown.

member.summary: Shrinks the internal data to the necessary minimum.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.GeneralShape2D.Fixate
member.summary: Set this shape into fixed state.
member.remarks: In fixed state it is no longer possible to change this shape, which allows for optimizations for iterators. Therefore it's a good idea to set shapes to fixed when it is clear that they are no longer changed. There is no way to "unfixate" a once fixed shape other then to append it to another .

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.GeneralShape2D.ShrinkWrap
member.summary: Shrink this shape, then set it into fixed state.
member.remarks: Calling this method is a good idea for longer living shapes after they are constructed.

member.summary: Split this shape into unbroken sub shapes. Each of the sub shapes will only contain one MoveTo segment.
member.returns: Array of fixed unbroken sub shapes.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Triangulator2BR
member.summary: 2D triangulator that can triangulate polygons with holes.

remarks.para: The polygons may not cross each other.
The algorithm used is a Constrained Delaunay triangulation.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Triangulator2BR.Triangulate(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Point2BR}},System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Triangulator2BR.Triangle},System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Point2BR})
member.summary: Triangulates given polygons and returns triangles and points.
member.param: Input. The polygons may not cross each other.
Output triangles, only contains the triangle point indices.
Output points, referred to by the point indices in the output triangles.

remarks.para: The polygons may not cross each other.
The algorithm used is a Constrained Delaunay triangulation.

member.example:
Below is an example demonstrating triangulating a square polygon with a hole in it. The hole is a smaller square.
This is the output of the triangulation:
(-2, 2), (1, 1), (-1, 1)
(-1, -1), (-2, 2), (-1, 1)
(1, 1), (2, 2), (1, -1)
(-2, 2), (2, 2), (1, 1)
(2, -2), (-1, -1), (1, -1)
(2, 2), (2, -2), (1, -1)
(-1, -1), (-2, -2), (-2, 2)
(2, -2), (-2, -2), (-1, -1)

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Triangulator2BR.Triangulate(System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Point2BR},System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Int32}},System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Triangulator2BR.Triangle})
member.summary: Triangulates given point set and polylines.
member.param: Represents polylines of fixed edges. May be empty or null. Each integer is an index in the inputPoints.

remarks.para: The polygons may not cross each other.
The algorithm used is a Constrained Delaunay triangulation.
This method may skip points that are very close together, in that case also the point index lists are modified.

member.example:
Below is an example demonstrating triangulating five points resulting in three triangles. The second triangulation is the same as the first one, but with one edge fixed (which forces more skinny triangles in this particular case).
This is the output of the first triangulation:
(2, 2), (-2, -2), (-2, 2)
(2, 2), (4, 0), (2, -2)
(2, -2), (-2, -2), (2, 2)
This is the output of the second triangulation:
(-2, -2), (4, 0), (2, -2)
(4, 0), (-2, -2), (2, 2)
(2, 2), (-2, -2), (-2, 2)

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Triangulator2BR.Triangulate(System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Point2BR},System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Int32}},System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Triangulator2BR.Triangle},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Triangulates given point set and polylines.
member.param: Represents polylines of fixed edges. May be empty or null. Each integer is an index in the inputPoints.
if set to true removes super triangles when finished triangulating.

remarks.para: The polygons may not cross each other.
The algorithm used is a Constrained Delaunay triangulation.
This method may skip points that are very close together, in that case also the point index lists are modified.

member.name: P:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Triangulator2BR.Triangle.Edge0HasOddFixCount
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether edge 0 has an odd fix count, i.e. if 3 then edge 0 was fixed 3 times, this could happen when 3 polylines run over this edge. Depending on the definition of inside/outside, when odd, the edge is a transition from inside to outside, when even, both sides are either inside/outside.

member.name: P:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Triangulator2BR.Triangle.Edge1HasOddFixCount
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether edge 1 has an odd fix count, i.e. if 3 then edge 0 was fixed 3 times, this could happen when 3 polylines run over this edge. Depending on the definition of inside/outside, when odd, the edge is a transition from inside to outside, when even, both sides are either inside/outside.

member.name: P:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Triangulator2BR.Triangle.Edge2HasOddFixCount
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether edge 2 has an odd fix count, i.e. if 3 then edge 0 was fixed 3 times, this could happen when 3 polylines run over this edge. Depending on the definition of inside/outside, when odd, the edge is a transition from inside to outside, when even, both sides are either inside/outside.

Index of the edge (between 0 and 2) outside which the point is if the result is false, -1 otherwise.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Ray2LR
member.summary: A 2D long rational () based ray consisting of a and a .
member.remarks:
The ray is represented by x(t) = + t * where t may have any value.
If used as a shape the ray is the representation of the parameter interval [0,1].

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Ray2LR.#ctor(WW.Math.Exact.Point2LR,WW.Math.Exact.Vector2LR)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the struct.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Ray2LR.#ctor(WW.Math.Exact.LongRational,WW.Math.Exact.LongRational,WW.Math.Exact.LongRational,WW.Math.Exact.LongRational)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the struct.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Ray2LR.Intersects(WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Ray2LR,System.Nullable{WW.Math.Exact.Point2LR}@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Calculates if 2 lines intersect.
member.param: Resulting intersection if there is one, null otherwise.
If lines intersect, then this parameter indicates whether the lines are parallel. In this case parameter intersection contains no valid value.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Ray2LR.GetIntersectionCoefficients(WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Ray2LR,WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Ray2LR,System.Nullable{WW.Math.Exact.LongRational}@,System.Nullable{WW.Math.Exact.LongRational}@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Calculate intersection parameters between two lines.
member.param: p, is null if there is no intersection or if the lines are parallel or if a has a zero direction.
q, is null if there is no intersection or if the lines are parallel or if b has a zero direction.
Whether the two lines are parallel.
member.returns: whether the two lines intersect.
member.remarks: The results is the solution of equation .Origin + p * .Direction = .Origin + q * .Direction.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Ray2LR.Intersects(WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Ray2LR,WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Segment2LR)
member.summary: Calculate intersection point between a ray and a segment.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Ray2LR.GetIntersectionCoefficients(WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Ray2LR,WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Segment2LR,System.Nullable{WW.Math.Exact.LongRational}@,System.Nullable{WW.Math.Exact.LongRational}@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Calculate intersection point between a ray and a segment.
member.param: p has value between 0 and 1 when there is 1 intersection. When the ray and segment are parallel or if a has a zero direction, then p is set to null.
q has value between 0 and 1 when there is 1 intersection. When the ray and segment are parallel or if b has a zero length, then q is set to null.
is set to true when the ray and segment are parallel.
member.returns: whether the ray and segment intersect.
member.remarks: The results is the solution of equation .Origin + p * .Direction = .Start + q * .GetDelta().

member.summary: Gets the least squares fit ray given specified set of points.
member.remarks: The least squares fit minimizes the vertical distance of the specified points to the best fitting ray.
member.exception: Thrown when number of points is less than two.

member.remarks: This is performing the whole clipping process without performing the actual clipping, so in most cases this is useless. But in some circumstances like outputting text as text this method is useful to check whether a given text is clipped.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR
member.summary: This class represents a 2D polygon: a closed plane figure with n sides (in 2D).
member.remarks:
This class has methods to:
calculate the polygon area (),
to test whether a point is inside the polygon (),
test whether the polygon is clockwise or not (),
do boolean operations (, , ).
Further static methods are also provided to allow to use other data structures than Polygon2BR.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR.GetIntersection(System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR},System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR})
member.summary: Get the intersection of two given regions.

remarks.para: Each region is defined by a set of polygons. If a polygon is counter clockwise, it is filled, if it's clockwise it represents a hole. Polygons of one region may not intersect each other. A polygon may touch itself though.
The outer polygon must always be counter clockwise (if there are holes, the hole must always be a cutout of a non-hole).

member.returns: The polygons building the intersection of both lists.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR.GetDifference(System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR},System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR})
member.summary: Get the difference of two given regions (region2 is subtracted from region1).

remarks.para: Each region is defined by a set of polygons. If a polygon is counter clockwise, it is filled, if it's clockwise it represents a hole. Polygons of one region may not intersect each other. A polygon may touch itself though.
The outer polygon must always be counter clockwise (if there are holes, the hole must always be a cutout of a non-hole).

member.returns: The polygons building the difference of the first minus the second list.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR.GetUnion(System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR},System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR})
member.summary: Get the union of two given regions.

remarks.para: Each region is defined by a set of polygons. If a polygon is counter clockwise, it is filled, if it's clockwise it represents a hole. Polygons of one region may not intersect each other. A polygon may touch itself though.
The outer polygon must always be counter clockwise (if there are holes, the hole must always be a cutout of a non-hole).

member.returns: The polygons building the union of the first and the second region.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR.GetExclusiveOr(System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR},System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR})
member.summary: Get the exclusive or (XOR) of two given regions.

remarks.para: Each region is defined by a set of polygons. If a polygon is counter clockwise, it is filled, if it's clockwise it represents a hole. Polygons of one region may not intersect each other. A polygon may touch itself though.
The outer polygon must always be counter clockwise (if there are holes, the hole must always be a cutout of a non-hole).

member.returns: The polygons building the exclusive or of the first and the second region.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR.GetConvexHull
member.summary: Calculates the convex hull using the Melkman algorithm (1987). This method assumes the specified polygon is a simple polygon (i.e. it does not cross itself).
member.remarks: The running time of this algorithm is O(n).

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR.GetConvexHull(System.Collections.Generic.IList{WW.Math.Exact.Point2BR})
member.summary: Calculates the convex hull using the Melkman algorithm (1987). This method assumes the specified polygon is a simple polygon (i.e. it does not cross itself). The input polygon is expected to be counter clockwise. The result is counter clockwise.
member.remarks: The running time of this algorithm is O(n).

member.name: T:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR.BooleanOperations.Event
member.summary: Represents an event for doing segment-segment intersection using a sweepline algorithm.
member.remarks: Events are sorted first along the x-axis, and then along the y-axis.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR.BooleanOperations.SweepLine
member.summary: Loosely based on bentley-ottman and "line segment intersection" by M. de Berg et al. TODO: Remark from the double-precision implementation of this algorithm: However this implementation doesn't use a balanced search tree for ordering segments along the sweepline as it would be difficult to circumvent precision issues in case of multiple overlapping line segments. For big rationals there are no precision issues, so can implement this more accurately.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR.BooleanOperations.SegmentWithIntersections.AddIntersection(WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR.BooleanOperations.Intersection)
member.summary: Adds the specified intersection. If there was already an intersection present with the same parameter or Point, then the intersection was not added.

member.name: P:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR.BooleanOperations.Intersection.Parameter
member.summary: Gets the parameter (0-1), 0 represents a segments start point, 1 represents the end point.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR.BooleanOperations.Region.Subdivide(WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Polygon2BR.BooleanOperations.Context)
member.summary: Subdivide the polygons in this region, in case polygons are self-intersecting. The direction of the segments in this region is ignored. Overlapping parts in the region are removed. Returns the resulting region, in which all polygons are counter clockwise.

member.summary: Gets the winding number of specified point with respect to specified polygon.
member.remarks: The winding number can be used to determine if a point is inside the polygon using the winding number. It depends on the definition of inside how this can be done. Useful definitions are an odd winding number, a positive winding number or a non-zero winding number.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Line2LR
member.summary: A 2D long rational () based line consisting of a and a .
member.remarks:
The line is represented by x(t) = + t * where t may have any value.
If used as a shape the line is the representation of the parameter interval [0,1].

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the struct.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the struct.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Line2LR.Intersects(WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Line2LR,System.Nullable{WW.Math.Exact.Point2LR}@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Calculates if 2 lines intersect.
member.param: Resulting intersection if there is one, null otherwise.
If lines intersect, then this parameter indicates whether the lines are parallel. In this case parameter intersection contains no valid value.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Line2LR.GetIntersectionCoefficients(WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Line2LR,WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Line2LR,System.Nullable{WW.Math.Exact.LongRational}@,System.Nullable{WW.Math.Exact.LongRational}@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Calculate intersection parameters between two lines.
member.param: p, is null if there is no intersection or if the lines are parallel or if a has a zero direction.
q, is null if there is no intersection or if the lines are parallel or if b has a zero direction.
Whether the two lines are parallel.
member.returns: whether the two lines intersect.
member.remarks: The results is the solution of equation .Origin + p * .Direction = .Origin + q * .Direction.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Line2LR.Intersects(WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Line2LR,WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Segment2LR)
member.summary: Calculate intersection point between a line and a segment.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Line2LR.GetIntersectionCoefficients(WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Line2LR,WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Segment2LR,System.Nullable{WW.Math.Exact.LongRational}@,System.Nullable{WW.Math.Exact.LongRational}@,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Calculate intersection point between a line and a segment.
member.param: p has value between 0 and 1 when there is 1 intersection. When the line and segment are parallel or if a has a zero direction, then p is set to null.
q has value between 0 and 1 when there is 1 intersection. When the line and segment are parallel or if b has a zero length, then q is set to null.
is set to true when the line and segment are parallel.
member.returns: whether the line and segment intersect.
member.remarks: The results is the solution of equation .Origin + p * .Direction = .Start + q * .GetDelta().

member.name: T:WW.Windows.Forms.ColorListPicker
member.summary: A control for picking a color from a list of colors.
member.remarks: This class mainly exists because the class System.Drawing.Design.ColorEditor is not part of the .NET Client Profile. Property contains the colors that the user can select from. member.summary: Constructor.
member.remarks: This is the fastest clipping option because clipping bounds are fixed at 0 <= Position <= 1, 0 <= Y <= 1, 0 <= Z <= 1 (in real space).

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.BlinnClipper4D.Fixed.Under
member.summary: Point is inside if real y is smaller than or equal to 1.
member.remarks: Intersection plane is defined by (0, -1, 0, 1). In Blinn terminology: boundary coordinate for point (x, y, z, w) is w - y.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.BlinnClipper4D.Fixed.Above
member.summary: Point is inside if real y is greater than or equal to 0.
member.remarks: Intersection plane is defined by (0, 1, 0, 0). In Blinn terminology: boundary coordinate for point (x, y, z, w) is y.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.BlinnClipper4D.Fixed.LeftOf
member.summary: Point is inside if real x is smaller than or equal to 1.
member.remarks: Intersection plane is defined by (-1, 0, 0, 1). In Blinn terminology: boundary coordinate for point (x, y, z, w) is w - position.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.BlinnClipper4D.Fixed.RightOf
member.summary: Point is inside if real x is greater than or equal to 0.
member.remarks: Intersection plane is defined by (1, 0, 0, 0). In Blinn terminology: boundary coordinate for point (x, y, z, w) is position.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.BlinnClipper4D.Fixed.InFrontOf
member.summary: Point is inside if real z is greater than or equal to 0.
member.remarks: Intersection plane is defined by (0, 0, 1, 0). In Blinn terminology: boundary coordinate for point (x, y, z, w) is z.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.BlinnClipper4D.Fixed.AtBackOf
member.summary: Point is inside if real z is smaller than or equal to 1.
member.remarks: Intersection plane is defined by (0, 0, -1, 1). In Blinn terminology: boundary coordinate for point (x, y, z, w) is w - z.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.BlinnClipper4D.Generic.Under
member.summary: Point is inside if real y is smaller than or equal to top.
member.remarks: Intersection plane is defined by (0, -1, 0, top). In Blinn terminology: boundary coordinate for point (x, y, z, w) is top * w - y.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.BlinnClipper4D.Generic.Above
member.summary: Point is inside if real y is greater than or equal to bottom.
member.remarks: Intersection plane is defined by (0, -1, 0, bottom). In Blinn terminology: boundary coordinate for point (x, y, z, w) is bottom * w - y.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.BlinnClipper4D.Generic.LeftOf
member.summary: Point is inside if real x is smaller than or equal to right.
member.remarks: Intersection plane is defined by (-1, 0, 0, right). In Blinn terminology: boundary coordinate for point (x, y, z, w) is right * w - position.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.BlinnClipper4D.Generic.RightOf
member.summary: Point is inside if real x is greater than or equal to left.
member.remarks: Intersection plane is defined by (-1, 0, 0, left). In Blinn terminology: boundary coordinate for point (x, y, z, w) is left * w - position.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.BlinnClipper4D.Generic.InFrontOf
member.summary: Point is inside if real z is greater than or equal to back.
member.remarks: Intersection plane is defined by (0, 0, -1, back). In Blinn terminology: boundary coordinate for point (x, y, z, w) is back * w - z.

member.name: T:WW.Math.Geometry.BlinnClipper4D.Generic.AtBackOf
member.summary: Point is inside if real z is smaller than or equal to front.
member.remarks: Intersection plane is defined by (0, 0, -1, front). In Blinn terminology: boundary coordinate for point (x, y, z, w) is front * w - z.

member.name: T:WW.Drawing.Rasterizer2D
member.summary: A 2D rasterizer that rasterizes onto a bitmap, without support for alpha blending or pen width.
member.remarks: This rasterizer is in some cases faster than for those methods that are implemented and can be used to speed up drawing, which may be necessary when drawing large amounts of dots, line segments and beziers. For relatively short line segments the clipping is taking relatively much time, so there is no performance gain.

member.summary: This class implements a filter for the Windows.Forms message pump allowing a specific message to be forwarded to the Control specified in the constructor. Adding and removing of the filter is done automatically.

remarks.para: Based on original code from cetkok: .
Add this message forwarder using . Add the forwarder e.g. when a control to which to forward messages to is entered (), and remove it again when the control is left ().

member.name: T:WW.ICloneable
member.summary: Interface for objects which clone themselves.
member.remarks: Implementing classes should make usefully independent copies. Useful depends on intended usage, so sometimes a deep copy may be necessary, and on other times not.

member.name: T:WW.Actions.Transaction
member.summary: A transaction consists of a group of commands that can be either committed or rolled back. The commands are executed as they are added in the method (by the interactor).

remarks.para: Commands within the transactions can be undone/redone, but when the last command was undone, the transaction is rolled back.
Consider e.g. the creation of a polyline, where the addition of each individual vertex is a command. If the user decides mid way he does not want the polyline, he can roll back the transaction.

member.summary: Gets minus .

member.name: M:WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Segment2LR.GetIntersectionParameters(WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Segment2LR,WW.Math.Exact.Geometry.Segment2LR,WW.Math.Exact.LongRational[]@,WW.Math.Exact.LongRational[]@)
member.summary: Calculate intersection parameter between two line segments.
member.remarks: The result is the solution of equation .Start + p * .GetDelta = .Start + q * .GetDelta.
member.param: A single parameter has a value between LongRational.Zero and LongRational.One. If the lines are parallel, the start p and end p of the overlapping line are returned. Lowest p value is first in the array. If the lines don't intersect then null is returned.
Analogue to . When lines are parallel, q values are returned in the order that the corresponding points are with respect to the p values.
member.returns: true if intersection occurred.

member.summary: Calculates if 2 line segment intersect.

member.summary: Returns the point on this segment that is closest to the specified point.

member.summary: Gets the projection of specified point onto this segment, normalized such that the projection of the start point is 0 and of the end point is 1. Returns NaN if this segment has a zero length.
member.remarks: Returns the distance from this segment's start point in the direction of the end point, normalized to 0-1 when the point's projection falls between the start and end point.

member.summary: Calculate intersection parameter between two line segments.
member.remarks: The result is the solution of equation .Start + p * .GetDelta = .Start + q * .GetDelta.
member.param: A single parameter has a value between 0 and 1. If the lines are parallel, the start p and end p of the overlapping line are returned. Lowest p value is first in the array. If the lines don't intersect then null is returned.
Analogue to . When lines are parallel, q values are returned in the order that the corresponding points are with respect to the p values.
member.returns: true if intersection occurred.

member.name: M:WW.Math.Geometry.Segment2D.GetIntersectionParameters(WW.Math.Geometry.Segment2D,WW.Math.Geometry.Segment2D,System.Double[]@,System.Double[]@,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculate intersection parameter between two line segments.
member.remarks: The result is the solution of equation .Start + p * .GetDelta = .Start + q * .GetDelta.
member.param: A single parameter has a value between 0 and 1. If the lines are parallel, the start p and end p of the overlapping line are returned. Lowest p value is first in the array. If the lines don't intersect then null is returned.
Analogue to . When lines are parallel, q values are returned in the order that the corresponding points are with respect to the p values.
The precision used to determine if segments are parallel or not.
member.returns: true if intersection occurred.

member.name: T:WW.IO.StreamUtil
member.summary: Contains utility methods for streaming.

member.name: M:WW.IO.StreamUtil.Forward(System.IO.Stream,System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Forward all data in the source stream to the target stream. The source stream position is moved back to its original position afterwards.
member.remarks: In case the source is a or , then the forwarding is done more efficiently by directly making use of their internal byte buffers. Otherwise the forwarding is done by reading page by page into a temporary byte buffer and writing each page to the target.

member.name: M:WW.IO.StreamUtil.Forward(System.IO.Stream,System.Int32,System.IO.Stream,System.Int32)
member.summary: Forward data of specified length in the source stream to the target stream. The source stream position is moved back to its original position afterwards.
member.remarks: In case the source is a or , then the forwarding is done more efficiently by directly making use of their internal byte buffers. Otherwise the forwarding is done by reading page by page into a temporary byte buffer and writing each page to the target.

member.name: T:WW.IO.MemoryPageCache
member.summary: This is a memory page cache. Caching can be useful in scenarios where memory pages are often allocated and released in succession to reduce the load on the garbage collector. Also time is saved because the byte array is not initialized like .NET does when allocating a new byte array.

member.name: M:WW.IO.MemoryPageCache.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class. Sets the page size to .

member.name: M:WW.IO.MemoryPageCache.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:WW.IO.MemoryPageCache.GetPage(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets a page (content is uninitialized).
member.exception: Thrown when the specified page size does not match this cache's page size.

member.name: M:WW.IO.MemoryPageCache.ReleasePage(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Releases the specified page. It is added to this cache if the page's length matches this cache's page size.

member.name: P:WW.IO.MemoryPageCache.PageSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the page size.
